'''Roy Rogers''' (born '''Leonard Franklin Slye'''; November 5, 1911 – July 6, 1998), nicknamed '''the King of the Cowboys''',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/|title=News from California, the nation and world|website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> was an American singer, actor, television host, [[Freemasonry|freemason]] and [[Rodeo|rodeo performer]].

Following early work under his given name, first as a co-founder of the [[Sons of the Pioneers]] and then as an actor, the rebranded Rogers then became one of the most famous and popular Western stars of his era.

He appeared in almost 90 motion pictures, as well as numerous episodes of his self-titled radio program that lasted for nine years. Between 1951 and 1957, he hosted ''[[The Roy Rogers Show]]'' television series. In many of them, he appeared with his wife, [[Dale Evans]]; his Golden Palomino, [[Trigger (horse)|Trigger]]; and his [[German Shepherd]], Bullet. Rogers is also best remembered for his signature song "[[Happy Trails (song)|Happy Trails]]".

His early roles were uncredited parts in films by fellow singing cowboy [[Gene Autry]]. His productions usually featured a [[sidekick]], often either [[Pat Brady (actor)|Pat Brady]], [[Andy Devine]], [[George "Gabby" Hayes]], or [[Smiley Burnette]].<ref name="smiley-obit">{{cite news|agency= [[Associated Press]] |title=Smiley Burnette, Movie re Off and Autry and Rogers, Dies at 55. Charlie Pratt of TV 'Petticoat Junction' Played Robles in Nearly 200 Westererns |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resthe=9D0CE7DF103FEF3BBC4052DtheFB466838C679EDE&legacy's=true|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 18, 1967 }}</ref>

Rogers was the only country singer to be inducted twice into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]]. Alongside [[Bob Hope]], [[Mickey Rooney]], and [[Tony Martin (American singer)|Tony Martin]], he's the recipient of four stars on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]; the latter of which was honored with the band mentioned above.

In his later years, he lent his name to the franchise chain of [[Roy Rogers Restaurants]].

==Early life==
Rogers was born Leonard Franklin Slye, the son of Mattie (née Womack) and Andrew "Andy" Slye in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]].<ref name="rr-bio">{{cite web |last1=Zwisohn |first1=Laurence |title=Happy Trails: The Life of Roy Rogers |url=https://royrogers.com/roy_rogers_bio.html |website=royrogers.com |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181205004802/https://royrogers.com/roy_rogers_bio.html |archive-date=December 5, 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The family lived in a tenement on 2nd Street, where [[Riverfront Stadium (Cincinnati)|Riverfront Stadium]] was later constructed. (Rogers later joked that he was born at second base.)<ref name="rr-bio"/> Len had three sisters: Kathleen, Mary, and Cleda. Dissatisfied with his job and city life, Andy and his brother Will built a {{convert|12|x|50|ft|adj=on}} houseboat from salvage lumber, and in July 1912 the Slye family traveled up the [[Ohio River]] towards [[Portsmouth, Ohio|Portsmouth]].<ref name="rr-bio"/> Desiring a more stable existence in Portsmouth, they purchased land on which they planned to build a house, but instead the [[Great Flood of 1913]] enabled them to move the houseboat onto their property and continue living in it on dry land.<ref name="rr-bio"/>

[[File:Roy Rogers Boyhood Home at Duck Run.jpg|thumb|Rogers's boyhood home at Duck Run, near [[Lucasville, Ohio]]]]
In 1919, the Slye family purchased a farm in Duck Run, near [[Lucasville, Ohio]], about {{convert|12|mi}} north of Portsmouth, and built a six-room house.<ref name="rr-bio"/> Andy soon realized that the farm alone would not provide sufficient income for his family, so he took a job at a Portsmouth shoe factory, living in Portsmouth during the week and returning home on weekends, bearing gifts following paydays. A notable gift was a horse on which young Len learned the basics of horsemanship.<ref name="rr-bio"/> Living on the farm with no radio, the family made their own entertainment. On Saturday nights, they often invited neighbors over for square dances, during which Len would sing, play mandolin, and call the square dances.<ref name="rr-bio"/> He also learned to [[yodel]] during this time, and with his mother they would use different yodels to communicate with each other across distances on the farm.<ref name="rr-bio"/>

Len attended high school in [[McDermott, Ohio]],<ref name="rr-bio"/> but after he completed his second year there, his family returned to Cincinnati, where his father worked at another shoe factory.<ref name="rr-bio"/> Realizing that his family needed his financial help, Len quit school and joined his father at the factory.<ref name="rr-bio"/> He tried to attend night school, but after being ridiculed for falling asleep in class, he quit school and never returned.

By 1929, after his older sister Mary and her husband had moved to [[Lawndale, California]], Len and his father quit their factory jobs, packed up their 1923 Dodge, and drove the family to California to visit Mary. They stayed for four months before returning to Ohio.<ref name="rr-bio"/> Soon after returning, Len had the opportunity to travel again to California with Mary's father-in-law, and the rest of the family followed in the spring of 1930. The Slye family rented a small house near Mary, and Len and his father found employment driving gravel trucks for a highway construction project.<ref name="rr-bio"/>

In spring 1931, after the construction company went bankrupt, Len traveled to [[Tulare, California]], where he found work picking peaches for [[Del Monte Foods|Del Monte]].<ref name="rr-bio"/> During this time, he lived in a labor camp similar to those depicted in John Steinbeck's novel ''[[The Grapes of Wrath]]''.<ref name="rr-bio"/> The economic hardship of the [[Great Depression]] was just as severe in California as it was in Ohio.

==Career==
===Music career===
After 19-year-old Len's return to Lawndale, his sister Mary suggested that he audition for the ''Midnight Frolic'' radio program, which was broadcast over [[KMCS]] in [[Inglewood, California|Inglewood]]. A few nights later, wearing a Western shirt that Mary had made for him, he overcame his shyness and appeared on the program playing guitar, singing, and yodeling.<ref name="rr-bio"/> A few days later, he was asked to join a local country music group, the Rocky Mountaineers.<ref name="rr-bio"/> He accepted the group's offer and became a member in August 1931.<ref name="rr-bio"/><ref>Green, p. 74.</ref>

By September 1931, Len hired the Canadian-born [[Bob Nolan]], who answered the group's classified ad in the ''Los Angeles Herald-Examiner'' that read, "Yodeler for old-time act, to travel. Tenor preferred." Nolan stayed with the group only a short time, but Len and he stayed in touch. Nolan was replaced by [[Tim Spencer (singer)|Tim Spencer]].<ref name="cmt">{{cite web|title=Sons of the Pioneers |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/sons_of_the_pioneers/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040223005617/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/sons_of_the_pioneers/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 23, 2004 |publisher=Country Music Television |access-date=April 29, 2014}}</ref>

In the spring of 1932, Len, Spencer, and another singer, Slumber Nichols, left the Rocky Mountaineers to form a trio, which soon failed. Throughout that year, Len and Spencer moved through a series of short-lived groups, including the International Cowboys and the O-Bar-O Cowboys. When Spencer left the O-Bar-O Cowboys to take a break from music, Len joined Jack LeFevre and His Texas Outlaws, who were a popular act on a local [[Los Angeles]] radio station.<ref>Green, p. 75.</ref>

In early 1933, Len, Nolan, and Spencer formed the Pioneers Trio, with Slye on guitar, Nolan on string bass, and Spencer as lead vocalist. They rehearsed for weeks refining their vocal harmonies. During this time, Len continued to work with his radio singing group, while Spencer and Nolan began writing songs for the trio.<ref name="cmt"/> In early 1934, the fiddle player Hugh Farr joined the group, adding a bass voice to their vocal arrangements. Later that year, the Pioneers Trio became the [[Sons of the Pioneers]] when a radio station announcer changed their name because he felt they were too young to be pioneers. The name was received well and fit the group, which was no longer a trio.<ref name="cmt"/>

By summer 1934, the popularity and fame of the Sons of the Pioneers extended beyond the Los Angeles area and quickly spread across the country through short syndicated radio segments that were later rebroadcast across the United States. The Sons of the Pioneers signed a recording contract with the newly founded [[Decca Records|Decca]] label and made their first commercial recording on August 8, 1934.<ref name="cmt"/> One of the first songs recorded during that first session was "[[Tumbling Tumbleweeds]]", written by Bob Nolan. Over the next two years, the Sons of the Pioneers recorded 32 songs for Decca, including the classic "[[Cool Water (song)|Cool Water]]".<ref name="encyclopedia">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Sons of the Pioneers |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3430600069.html |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia.com |access-date=August 27, 2011}}</ref>

===Film career===
[[File:Lynne Roberts-Roy Rogers in Billy the Kid Returns.jpg|thumb|Lynne Roberts and Rogers in ''[[Billy the Kid Returns]]'', 1938]]
From his first film appearance in 1935, Len worked steadily in [[Western (genre)|Western]] films, including a large supporting role as a singing cowboy while still billed as Leonard Slye in a Gene Autry movie. In 1938, Autry demanded more money for his work, so there was a competition for a new singing cowboy (that they could pay less). Many singers sought the job, including [[Willie Phelps]] of the Phelps brothers, who appeared in early Western movies. Len ended up winning the contest and was given the stage name Roy Rogers by [[Republic Pictures]], suggesting the western-sounding name Roy and combining it with the surname of the popular western comic entertainer [[Will Rogers]].

He was assigned the leading role in ''[[Under Western Stars]]''. He became a matinee idol, a competitor with Autry as the nation's favorite [[singing cowboy]]. In addition to his own movies, he played a supporting role in the [[John Wayne]] classic ''[[Dark Command]]'' (1940), which also featured one of his future sidekicks, George "Gabby" Hayes. He became a major box-office attraction. Unlike other stars, the vast majority of his leading roles allowed him to play a character with his own name, in the manner of Autry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001678/|title=Roy Rogers|website=[[IMDb]] }}</ref>
[[File:Roy Rogers - Hart - 1938.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Publicity photo of Rogers and [[Lynne Roberts|Mary Hart]] for ''[[Shine On, Harvest Moon (1938 film)|Shine On, Harvest Moon]]'', 1938]]
In the ''[[Motion Picture Herald]]'' [[Top Ten Money Making Stars Poll#Top Ten Western Stars|Top Ten Money-Making Western Stars]] poll, Rogers was listed for 16 consecutive years, from 1939 to 1954, holding first place from 1943 to 1954 until the poll ceased.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hardy|first=Phil|title=The Encyclopedia of Western Movies|year=1984|publisher=Woodbury Press|location=Minneapolis|isbn=978-0-8300-0405-8}}</ref> He appeared in the similar ''[[BoxOffice (magazine)|BoxOffice]]'' poll from 1938 to 1955, holding first place from 1943 to 1952. In the final three years of that poll, he was second only to [[Randolph Scott]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b-westerns.com/terms5.htm |title=Motion Picture Herald and Boxoffice Polls |publisher=B-westerns.com |access-date=October 31, 2011}}</ref> These two polls are only an indication of the popularity of series stars, but Rogers also appeared in the [[Top Ten Money Making Stars Poll]] of all films in 1945 and 1946.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.quigleypublishing.com/MPalmanac/Top10/Top10_lists.html |title=Top Ten Money Making Stars |publisher=Quigleypublishing.com |access-date=August 9, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221063625/http://www.quigleypublishing.com/MPalmanac/Top10/Top10_lists.html |archive-date=December 21, 2014 }}</ref>

Rogers was an idol for many children through his films and television shows. Most of his postwar films were in [[Trucolor]] during an era when almost all other [[B westerns]] were black and white. Some of his movies would segue into animal adventures, in which his horse, Trigger, would go off on his own for a while with the camera following him.

With money from Rogers's films and from his public appearances going to [[Republic Pictures]], he brought a clause into his 1940 contract with the studio where he would have the right to his likeness, voice, and name for merchandising.<ref>Phillips, p. 38.</ref> There were Roy Rogers [[action figure]]s, cowboy adventure novels, and [[playset]]s, as well as a comic strip, a long-lived [[Dell Comics]] comic book series (''Roy Rogers Comics'') written by [[Gaylord Du Bois]], and a variety of marketing successes.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Schelly |first1=William |title=American Comic Book Chronicles: The 1950s |date=2013 |publisher=TwoMorrows Publishing |isbn=9781605490540 |page=50}}</ref> Rogers was second only to [[Walt Disney]] in the number of items featuring his name.<ref>Enss and Kazanjian, p. 132.</ref>

The Sons of the Pioneers continued their popularity and have not stopped performing from the time Rogers started the group, replacing members as they retired or died (all original members are dead). Although he was no longer an active member, they often appeared as his backup group in films, radio, and television, and he would occasionally appear with them in performances up until his death.

He met Dale Evans in 1944 when they were cast in a film together. They were well known as advocates for [[adoption]] and as founders and operators of children's charities. They adopted several children. Both were outspoken Christians throughout their marriage.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Miller Davis |first1=Elise |title=The Answer Is God |url=https://archive.org/details/answerisgodinspi00davi |url-access=registration |date=1955 |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York |lccn=55009539 |pages=[https://archive.org/details/answerisgodinspi00davi/page/104 104–112] }}</ref> Beginning in 1949, they were part of the Hollywood Christian Group, founded by their friend, Louis Evans Jr., the organizing pastor of [[Bel Air Church]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Fuller Seminary: The Original Five|url = http://www.seekgod.ca/fuller1.htm#evans|website = www.seekgod.ca|access-date = November 5, 2015|archive-date = July 11, 2007|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070711155115/http://www.seekgod.ca/fuller1.htm#evans|url-status = dead}}</ref> The group met in Henrietta Mears's home and later in the home of Evans and [[Colleen Townsend]], after their marriage. [[Billy Graham]] and [[Jane Russell]] were also part of this group. In 1956, the Hollywood Christian Group became Bel Air Church.

In [[Apple Valley, California]], where they later made their home, streets, highways, and civic buildings have been named after them in recognition of their efforts on behalf of homeless and handicapped children. Rogers was also an active [[Freemason]] and a [[Shriner]] and was noted for his support of their charities.
[[File:Roy Rogers and Gail Davis 1948.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Publicity photo of Rogers and [[Gail Davis]], 1948]]
Rogers and Evans' famous theme song, "Happy Trails", was written by Evans; they sang it as a duet to sign off their television show. In fall 1962, they cohosted a comedy-Western-variety program, ''[[The Roy Rogers and Dale Evans Show]]'', aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. It was cancelled after three months, losing in the ratings to ''[[The Jackie Gleason Show]]'' on [[Columbia Broadcasting Company|CBS]]. Rogers also made numerous [[cameo appearance]]s on other popular television shows, starring as himself or other cowboy-type characters, such as in an episode of ''[[Wonder Woman (TV series)|Wonder Woman]]'' called "[[List of Wonder Woman episodes|The Bushwackers]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewb.com/shows/wonder-woman/pilot-the-new-original-wonder-woman/b6dad16f-4e16-41f0-8534-590f88ef6c44 |title=Wonder Woman: Pilot: The New Original Wonder Woman |publisher=Thewb.com |access-date=October 31, 2011}}</ref>

Rogers owned a Hollywood production company, which produced his own series. It also filmed other undertakings, including the 1955–1956 CBS Western series ''[[Brave Eagle]]'', starring [[Keith Larsen]] as a young, peaceful [[Cheyenne]] chief, [[Kim Winona]] as Morning Star, his romantic interest, and the [[Hopi]] Indian Anthony Numkena as Keena, Brave Eagle's foster son.

In 1968, Rogers licensed his name to the [[Marriott Corporation]], which converted its Hot Shoppes restaurants into Roy Rogers Restaurants, with which he otherwise had no involvement.

Rogers returned to Lubbock in 1970 to headline the [[Texas Tech University]] Intercollegiate Rodeo with Evans. In 1975, his last motion picture, ''Macintosh and T.J.'' was filmed at the 6666 Ranch in [[King County, Texas|King County]], 90 miles east of Lubbock and near the O-
Bar-O Ranch in [[Kent County, Texas|Kent County]].<ref name=rogersintexas>{{cite news|url=https://www.lubbockonline.com/news/20190309/caprock-chronicles-king-of-cowboys-roy-rogers-hungry-life-on-llano-estacado|title=Caprock Chronicles: The King of the Cowboys: Roy Rogers' Hungry Life on the Llano Estacado|newspaper=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|author=Chuck Lanehart|date=March 9, 2019|access-date=March 9, 2019}}</ref>

==Personal life==
[[File:RoyRogersDaleEvansKBF1970s.jpg|thumb|upright|Rogers and Dale Evans at [[Knott's Berry Farm]] in the 1970s]]
In 1932, a palomino colt foaled in California was named "Golden Cloud"; when Rogers acquired him, he renamed him Trigger. Rogers also owned a [[thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorse]] named Triggairo, that won 13 career races, including the 1975 [[El Encino Stakes]] at [[Santa Anita Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pedigreequery.com/triggairo |title=Triggairo Horse Pedigree |publisher=Pedigree Online Thoroughbred Database |access-date=October 31, 2011}}</ref>

Rogers had been on tour with the O-Bar-O Cowboys in June 1933, and while they were performing in [[Roswell, New Mexico]], a caller to a radio station, Grace Arline Wilkins, promised Rogers that she would bake him a pie if he sang "The Swiss Yodel". They were married in Roswell on June 11, 1936, having corresponded since their first meeting.<ref name="bio"/> In 1941, the couple adopted a daughter, Cheryl Darlene. Two years later, Grace gave birth to daughter Linda Lou. A son, Roy Jr. ("Dusty"), was born in 1946; Grace died of complications from the birth a few days later, on November 3.<ref>Wyatt, Tom and Greenland, David. "B Western Cowboys: Part I", ''[[Classic Images]]''. September 2022</ref>

Rogers met Dale Evans in 1944, when they were cast in a film together. They fell in love soon after Grace's death, and Rogers proposed to her during a rodeo at [[Chicago Stadium]]. They married on New Year's Eve in 1947 at the Flying L Ranch in [[Davis, Oklahoma]], where they had filmed ''[[Home in Oklahoma]]'' a few months earlier. Together they had a child and adopted four more: Robin Elizabeth, who had [[Down syndrome]] and died of complications of [[mumps]] shortly before her second birthday; three adopted daughters, Mimi, Dodie, and Debbie; and one adopted son, Sandy.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Evans wrote about the loss of their daughter Robin in her book ''Angel Unaware''. Rogers and Evans remained married until his death.<ref name="bio">Phillips, pp. 13–15.</ref>

In 1955, Rogers and Evans purchased a 168-acre (68 ha) ranch near [[Chatsworth, California]], complete with a hilltop ranch house,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/article/zz/20111105/NEWS/111109754|title=Roy Rogers' 'Happy Trails' led to San Fernando Valley's Chatsworth|website=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |date=November 5, 2011}}</ref> expanding it to 300 acres (121 ha).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1998-jul-07-mn-1431-story.html|title=Rogers' House a Chatsworth Landmark|first=MARTHA L.|last=WILLMAN|date=July 7, 1998|via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://a-drifting-cowboy.blogspot.com/2012/02/double-r-bar-ranch-roy-rogers.html|title=A drifting cowboy: Double R Bar Ranch – Roy Rogers' Chatsworth Home|date=February 5, 2012|website=A-drifting-cowboy.blogspot.com}}</ref>

After their daughter Debbie was killed in a church bus accident in 1964, they moved to the 67-acre (27 ha) Double R Bar Ranch in Apple Valley, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://patch.com/california/northridge/roy-rogers-ranch-sold-at-auction|title=Roy Rogers' Ranch Sold at Auction|date=July 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hotprop-roy-rogers-20190415-story.html|title=Time to round up a buyer for Roy Rogers' old ranch in Victorville|last=Beale|first=Lauren|date=April 15, 2019|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=April 16, 2019}}</ref>

Rogers was a [[Freemason]] and a member of Hollywood (California) Lodge No. 355, the Scottish Rite Valley of Los Angeles, and [[Shrine Auditorium|Al Malaikah Shrine Temple]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nymasons.org/about-freemasonry/famous-masons-i.html | publisher=MWGLNY | title=Famous Masons | date=January 2014 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110010123/http://www.nymasons.org/about-freemasonry/famous-masons-i.html | archive-date=November 10, 2013 }}</ref> He was awarded the honorary 33rd degree of the [[Scottish Rite]] in 1975.

He was also a pilot and the owner of a [[Cessna Bobcat]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=AOPA Pilot|title=A Plane Crazy America|page=79|date=May 2014}}</ref>

Rogers supported [[Barry Goldwater]] in the [[1964 United States presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QfHXAAAAQBAJ&q=roy%20rogers | title=When Hollywood Was Right: How Movie Stars, Studio Moguls, and Big Business Remade American Politics| isbn=9781107650282| last1=Critchlow| first1=Donald T.| date=October 21, 2013| publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref>

===Death===
Rogers died of [[congestive heart failure]] on July 6, 1998, aged 86, in Apple Valley, California. He was buried at Sunset Hills Memorial Park in Apple Valley, as was his wife Dale Evans three years later.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brooks|first1=Patricia|title=Laid to Rest in California: A Guide to the Cemeteries and Grave Sites of the Rich and Famous |chapter=Chapter 8: East L.A. and the Desert |pages=235–7 |year=2006|publisher=Globe Pequot Press|location=Guilford, Connecticut|isbn=978-0762741014|last2=Brooks |first2=Jonathan |oclc= 70284362}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CE8xiT3pV6QC&q=roy+rogers+dale+evans+sunset+hills&pg=PT535|title=Handbook of Texas Music|first=Laurie E.|last=Jasinski|date=February 22, 2012|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|isbn=9780876112977|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="newyorktimes">{{cite news |last1=Severo |first1=Richard |title=Roy Rogers, Singing Cowboy, Dies at 86 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/arts/roy-rogers-singing-cowboy-dies-at-86.html |url-access=subscription |access-date=September 9, 2019 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 7, 1998 |issue=July 7, 1998}}</ref>

==Honors and awards==
[[File:RoyRogersperformingKBF.jpg|thumb|upright|Rogers performing at [[Knott's Berry Farm]]]]
On February 8, 1960, Rogers was honored with three stars on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]: for Motion Pictures at 1752 Vine Street, for Television at 1620 Vine Street, and for Radio at 1733 Vine Street.<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|title=Hollywood Star Walk: Roy Rogers |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=July 7, 1998 |url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/roy-rogers/ |access-date=April 29, 2014}}</ref> In 1983 he was awarded the [[Golden Boot Awards|Golden Boot Award]],<ref name="golden-boot">{{cite web|title=Legacy |publisher=Golden Boot Awards |url=http://www.goldenbootawards.com/home.html |access-date=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
and in 1996 he received the Golden Boot Founder's Award.<ref name="golden-boot"/>

In 1967, Rogers, with Choctaw blood on his mother's side, was named ''outstanding Indian citizen of the year'' by a group of Western tribes.<ref name="newyorktimes"/>

In 1976, Rogers and Evans were inducted into the [[Western Performers Hall of Fame]] at the [[National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum]] in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], and in 1995 he was inducted again as a founding member of the Sons of the Pioneers.<ref name="western-performers-hf">{{cite web|title=Great Western Performers |publisher=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |url=http://www.nationalcowboymuseum.org/info/awards-hof/Western-Performers.aspx |access-date=April 29, 2014}}</ref>

Rogers received recognition from the State of Arkansas, appointed by the governor of that state with an [[Arkansas Traveler (honorary title)|Arkansas Traveler]] certificate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aymag.com/historical-gems-history-arkansas-traveler/|title=Historical Gems: History of the Arkansas Traveler |author=Rhodes, Sunny |publisher=AY Magazine |date=July 1, 2016}}</ref>

Rogers was also twice elected to the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]], first as a member of the Sons of the Pioneers in 1980, and again as a soloist in 1988. In 2018, he was inducted to the [[National Multicultural Western Heritage Museum]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Hall of Fame Inductees |url=https://nmwhm.org/hall-of-fame-inductees/ |website=National Multicultural Western Heritage Museum |access-date=June 5, 2023}}</ref> As of August 2022, he was the only person elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame twice.<ref name="cmhf">{{cite web|title=Roy Rogers |publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame |url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/artists/artist-detail/roy-rogers |access-date=April 29, 2014}}</ref> In 2001, a Golden Palm Star on the [[Palm Springs, California]], [[Palm Springs Walk of Stars|Walk of Stars]] was dedicated to him and Dale Evans.<ref name="palm-springs">{{cite web |url=http://www.palmspringswalkofstars.com/web-storage/Stars/Stars%20dedicated%20by%20date.pdf |title=Palm Springs Walk of Stars |publisher=Palm Springs Walk of Stars |access-date=August 9, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013165655/http://www.palmspringswalkofstars.com/web-storage/Stars/Stars%20dedicated%20by%20date.pdf |archive-date=October 13, 2012 }}</ref>

Rogers's cultural influence is reflected in numerous songs, including "If I Had a Boat" by [[Lyle Lovett]], "Roy Rogers" by [[Elton John]] on his 1973 album ''[[Goodbye Yellow Brick Road]]'', and "Should've Been a Cowboy" by Toby Keith. Rogers himself makes an appearance in the music video for the song "[[Heroes and Friends]]" by [[Randy Travis]]. Rogers is referenced in numerous films, including ''[[Die Hard]]'' (1988) in which the [[Bruce Willis]] character [[John McClane]] used the pseudonym "Roy" and remarks, "I was always kinda partial to Roy Rogers actually." In the television series ''[[American Dad!]]'', the character Roger uses "Roy Rogers" as a pseudonym in the episode "[[Roy Rogers McFreely]]". In the movie ''[[City Slickers]]'', the [[Jack Palance]] character Curly sings the song "[[Tumbling Tumbleweeds]]" while the [[Billy Crystal]] character Mitch is playing the harmonica.

==Filmography ==

==Box office ranking==
For a number of years exhibitors voted Rogers among the most popular stars in the country:
*1942 – 2nd most popular Western star (following [[Gene Autry]])<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11349903 |title=The Screen's First Money-Spinneks for 1942. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=February 27, 1943 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=6, The Argus Week-end Magazine |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
*1943 – most popular Western star
*1944 – 24th most popular star in the U.S.; most popular Western star<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1110315 |title=Bing Crosby America's Screen Favourite. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=March 24, 1945 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=8, The Argus Week-end Magazine |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
*1945 – most popular Western star;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59346311 |title=Film Cable From Hollywood. |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]] |location=Perth |date=December 2, 1945 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=5, Sunday Times Comics |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> 10th most popular star<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128318284 |title=Box Office Stars. |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |location=Adelaide |date=December 28, 1945 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
*1946 – 10th most popular star in the US; most popular Western star
*1947 – 12th most popular star in the US; most popular Western star
*1948 – 17th most popular star in the US; most popular Western star<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103710961 |title=The Box Office Draw. |newspaper=[[Goulburn Evening Penny Post|Goulburn Evening Post]] |location=New South Wales |date=December 31, 1948 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=3, daily and evening edition |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
*1949 – 18th most popular star in the US; most popular Western star
*1950 – 19th (US);<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18154454 |title=Filmdom Ranks Its Money-Spinning Stars Best at Box-Office. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald|Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=March 30, 1950 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> most popular Western star
*1951 – most popular Western star
*1952 – most popular Western star (for the 10th year in a row)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69428232 |title=Comedians Top Films Poll. |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tasmania |date=December 27, 1952 |access-date=October 5, 2014 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
